awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Improving Spectrum Efficiency for Hyper-Dense IoT Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The emerging Internet of Things (IoT) technology will enable a whole new set of applications, imposing far reaching influence on many aspects of society, including management of health, transportation, agriculture, safety and emergency and disaster response. At the same time, the massive growth of IoT deployments poses several grand challenges to the wireless industry for their successful operation. This project aims to develop novel IoT architectures and algorithms to enable large-scale IoT deployments. In particular, through close collaboration of three academic institutions and industry, the proposed research will make advances by introducing holistic, cross-layer design framework and protocols for improving spectral/energy efficiency and latency of massive IoT networks. The research outcomes will support emerging standardization activities to enable IoT in next-generation wireless networks. 

This project aims at tackling the following challenges: 1) System-Centric Waveform Design for Massive IoT: The researchers will couple stochastic geometry techniques and ambiguity functions of carrier waveforms to perform system-wide capacity analysis, compare waveform candidates for deployment suitability, develop joint equalizer and waveform designs for massive IoT deployments, and propose new waveforms having a good spectral efficiency, interference resilience, and latency characteristics. 2) Graph-based Radio Resource Management: Judicious radio resource management is critical to the proper functioning of hyper-dense IoT networks. The project will exploit weighted partitioning and matching tools from graph theory to develop waveform-aware dynamic resource allocation schemes to suppress mutual interference among a diverse set of wireless IoT links and improve spectrum utilization efficiency in single-hop and multi-hop massive IoT deployments. 3) Core network Connection Efficiency: Rethinking the core network functions for connection of massive IoT is required as they are not designed considering the IoT traffic characteristics. The project will develop and rigorously study an aggregation based connectivity model to manage multiple IoT device traffic using the same resources (i.e., bearers). For efficient groupings of the IoT devices that will share the same connection, researchers will use efficient evolutionary clustering methods, while giving preference to the interference minimizing groups obtained in earlier thrusts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Internet of things (IoT) technology has offered a new set of applications, imposing far reaching influences on multifarious aspects of the society. At the same time, it has brought grand challenges to the wireless industry, including but not limited to the difficulty of allocating control/data channel resources to a large number of IoT devices. In this project, we aimed to develop novel physical (PHY), medium access control (MAC), and core network IoT architectures and algorithms to enable massive and heterogeneous IoT deployments. A comprehensive, cross-layer study into waveform designs, graph-based radio resource management, and traffic aggregation based core network scheduling solutions have been explored.

The scientific merit of the project is centered around exploring models and techniques for cross-layer investigation into PHY, MAC, and core network issues for enabling massive IoT deployments in future wireless networks. To this end, we first aimed at utilization of the same cellular line by multiple IoT devices by letting them share the same international subscriber identity (IMSI) number in their SIM cards. Depending on the traffic patterns, we developed both optimal and heuristic based near-optimal but much faster grouping algorithms which find out the IoT devices that can share their cellular line without any overlap in their traffic patterns. We considered slight shifts in the traffic patterns of devices to group more devices into each cellular line too. The 5G core network considers the devices using the same cellular line (and IMSI number) in turns as the same device, utilizing the memory resources at the core efficiently. Through simulations and experiments in our 5G core network testbed, we obtained extensive results and proof-of-concept implementation of the proposed system and showed the benefit of the proposed system in various scenarios. We also considered integration of UAVs into IoT networks to provide access and data collection services to ground IoT devices as relays between IoT devices and cellular infrastructure. We have developed novel solutions that let multiple UAVs find out their optimal paths collaboratively (i.e., helping each other) during their missions. We also explored some related aspects such as security implications of proposed solutions and algorithms and developed related extensions that will ensure robust and resilient functioning of the proposed solutions.

The solutions and protocols developed in this research helped towards building holistic, cross-layer design framework for improving spectral/energy efficiency and latency of massive IoT networks. Through close collaboration of three academic institutions, the proposed research developed novel architectures and protocols to enable scalable and efficient IoT deployments in next generation wireless networks, bringing transformative changes and benefits to the society. The project trained several graduate and undergraduate students from under-represented populations with diverse backgrounds and resulted in doctoral degrees in wireless communication, IoT and UAV networks areas. Collaboration efforts between the involved institutions have initiated a long-term relationship. Institutional resources (5G testbed) has increased and the research team has been exposed to the NSF PAWR supported testbeds (AERPAW). Project outputs have also been disseminated via publications and presentations in conferences and journals.
